title: Immigration and foreign nationals
prayerSummary: Pray for Japanese officials and organizations as they oversee the influx of foreign nationals.
Pray for Christian foreign nationals to be a blessing to their Japanese neighbors in schools, workplaces, and communities.
Pray that Japanese churches will reach out to foreign nationals and partner with diaspora groups and ethnic churches.
textBody:
When Hoa reached the cash register at the convenience store, she noticed the employee’s nametag. They had the same last name.
“Are you from Vietnam?” she asked in Vietnamese.
“Yes! Are you?”
They found out that they were studying at the same university and decided to meet for lunch that week.

The influx of foreign nationals has increased in recent years. After a decrease due to COVID-19, this number reached an all-time high in 2022.<sup>1</sup> Many come as professionals, skilled workers, or students. Others come as spouses. In 2019 the government made a significant policy change to bring in workers for industries such as manufacturing, agriculture, and nursing care to help meet critical labor shortages.

As a mainly homogenous society that values conformity, Japan faces numerous challenges integrating new people. Foreign nationals also face challenges. They need to adjust to the culture, working environment, and high cost of living in Japan, as well as learn the language.

Some of the foreign nationals are missionaries on religious visas. Other Christians have intentionally found secular jobs in Japan and are building relationships in their workplaces. Churches are being planted among diaspora groups like Filipinos, Brazilians, and Chinese, and several cities now have multi-ethnic international churches.

photos.title: A large crowd of visitors at a prominent shrine in Kyoto (Fushimi Inari Taisha) on New Year's Day.

A visitor at Meiji shrine bows before passing through the torii gate. A torii gate is seen as an entryway into sacred space.
A shrine on a small beach island (Aoshima) in Miyazaki prefecture.
A man prays at a local neighborhood shrine in Chiba prefecture.
Sensoji, a popular Buddhist temple in Tokyo.
A child and his guardian wave incense over themselves. This is a common purification or healing ritual at Buddhist temples.
A young man locating his omikuji, or fortune-telling paper.
Charms for protection and good luck called omamori on sale at a shrine.
A woman shops for a charm at a temple.
Visitors at Meiji shrine write prayer requests on wooden tablets called ema.
A child's prayer written on a prayer tablet at a shrine.
An elderly woman prays at the altar of a popular temple in Tokyo.
A woman drops coins in the offering box in front of a monkey statue, which is considered a patron of safety in childbirth.
Shrines often feature in important celebrations and rites of passage for Japanese families.
A couple takes wedding photographs at a shrine. In Japan, important life events are often celebrated at shrines.
Shichi-go-san is a festival in November celebrating children at the ages of seven, five, and three. It is often commemorated at shrines.
Summer festivals at shrines are often popular events for youth and young adults to attend with friends, family, or dates.
